I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During 1999 the Government of Sri Lanka requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to provide project preparatory technical assistance (TA) to support the preparation of a 
sector investment project that will address priority natural resource and environmental problems 
in key subsectors. The project will support the Government's initiatives to establish a consistent 
and integrated natural resource and environmental management (NREM) framework, to develop 
efficient systems, and to provide services in priority subsectors to effectively manage and 
mitigate adverse impacts on natural resources and the environment. An ADB TA Fact-Finding 
Mission visited Sri Lanka during September 2002 and held discussions with the Treasury, 
Ministry of Policy Implementation-External Resources Department, Ministry of Environment and 
Natural Resources (MENR), Ministry of Lands,  Ministry of Western Region, Ministry of Home 
Affairs, provincial councils and local government, the World Bank, and the Royal Netherlands 
Embassy. The Mission and the various Government agencies reached understanding on the TA 
objectives, scope, cost, terms of reference, and implementation arrangements. The TA is 
included in the 2002 country program for Sri Lanka.1   
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Government’s vision for sustainable development requires strategies that support 
economic growth and poverty reduction; the integration of economic, social, and environmental 
aspects; and the active participation of all stakeholders. The sustainable management of natural 
resources will be essential if this vision is to be achieved.  
 
3.  Currently  in  Sri  Lanka,  increasing  population  pressure  and  economic  growth  have 
depleted renewable and nonrenewable resources, reduced the forest cover, degraded land and 
water, encroached into protected areas, and produced adverse environmental impacts. These 
impacts are detailed in Sri Lanka's State of the Environment Report, 2001, and affect all regions 
of the country. This loss of resources will increasingly constrain development and adversely 
impact livelihoods, and the poor and vulnerable. The current systems used for NREM are 
inadequate  due  to  the  absence  of  a  comprehensive  policy  framework  and  a  consistent 
legislative  and  regulatory  base,  as  well  as  weak  institutional,  planning,  and  enforcement 
systems. A range of land resource management, and legal and institutional issues must be 
addressed to promote more efficient land allocation and use. 
  
4.  The Government has indicated a commitment to developing an integrated approach to 
NREM  with  the  establishment  of  the  MENR  in  2001,  and  the  development  of  a  draft 
environmental policy. The Government is also preparing a national environmental action plan. 
Furthermore, projects supported by ADB2 and the Netherlands are helping the Government 
prepare a number of natural resource subsector policies and plans (forest, wildlife, water 
resources, biodiversity, and coastal resources). At the subsector level, progress has been made 
with policy development and planning, drafting of new legislation, and institutional capacity

building. It is important that the subsector policies, strategies, and legislative and regulatory 
approaches  are  harmonized  and  integrated  across  the  subsectors  for  effective  overall 
management of natural resources and the environment. 
 
5.  Some natural resource and environmental problems for example, water degradation due 
to  agricultural  and  industrial  pollution,  and  solid  waste  management  will  require  providing 
specific services for treatment and mitigation. At the same time, a more comprehensive range of 
services extending to livelihood improvement is likely to be required to address problems related 
to community-based management of natural resources and to maintain and develop ecologically 
significant sites used for both community livelihood and ecotourism. The provision of these 
services is currently inadequate; it is often the responsibility of local government agencies that, 
unfortunately, lack the required institutional, human, and financial capacity. 
 
6.  The Government estimates that about 27% of the population in 1995 was in poverty; 
with a larger group considered vulnerable as their household income level was only slightly 
above the poverty thresholds. In Sri Lanka the levels of consumption poverty are significantly 
higher than those of human poverty, indicating that poverty is linked more to income level than 
to access to basic services. As 90% of the poor live in rural areas and a significant percentage 
of  these  households  are  small  farmers,  the  management  of  natural  resources  and  the 
environment is a key factor influencing their poverty status, as degraded resource systems will 
limit their ability to generate sufficient assets to move beyond poverty. Current population and 
economic growth forecasts suggest that the overall demand for natural resources in Sri Lanka 
will increase by approximately 50% above the existing level within 20 years. Given the high 
levels of consumption poverty and the large group assessed as vulnerable, Sri Lanka faces a 
growing poverty risk if effective NREM systems are not established. The Government’s poverty 
reduction  strategy  identifies  innovative  environmental  management  as  one  of  the  priority 
strategies for poverty reduction (Appendix 1).3 
 
7.  In 2000–2001, an ADB advisory technical assistance (ADTA) on sustainable natural 
resource  management,  achieved  a  number  of  outcomes  in  terms  of  advancing  policy 
development to improve land resource management, and in preparing recommendations for 
institutional and legal reform to improve natural resource management.4 The ADTA's outcome 
provides the basis for developing an NREM framework. The ADTA recommended that further 
support be provided in three key areas: (i) strengthening institutional capacity for environmental 
and  natural  resource  management  at  national  and  provincial  levels,  and  for  sustainable 
development  planning;  (ii)  establishing  apex  agencies,  and  improving  land  resource 
management, and forestry and biodiversity coordination; and (iii) reforming inconsistent or 
overlapping laws and regulations on the management of natural resources.   
 
8.  On land  resource policy, the Government is preparing a new land ownership act to 
facilitate the alienation and transfer of land. While this legislation will lead to efficient transfer of 
land, it will not resolve numerous land resource policy and legal issues that arise from the large 
number of agencies involved with land administration and associated overlapping functional 
mandates. The World Bank is considering expanding the existing Land Titling Project to include 
land resource policy and the related legal and ni stitutional aspects. The Government has 
prepared  a  national  involuntary  resettlement  policy  that  details  the  arrangements  for 
compensation and rehabilitation.

9.  To develop an effective integrated NREM framework, the Government will need to 
create or strengthen management, planning, and regulatory systems, and institutional capacity 
at the national, regional, and local levels. These changes will be particularly important as part of 
the rehabilitation process in the north and the east. The lack of consistent policy, institutional, 
and  legal  mandates  across  agencies  (national,  regional,  and  local),  and  the  partial 
decentralization  and  devolution  of  natural  resource  and  environmental  management  and 
planning functions have resulted in a lack of effective management, planning, implementation, 
and enforcement. 
 
10.  Although the devolution and decentralization process under the 13th Amendment to the 
Constitution is incomplete, the Government has established five regional ministries, with a 
mandate for physical planning, economic development, and coordination. The World Bank 
Environmental  Action  1  Project  is  supporting  the  Government  in  decentralizing  central 
environmental authority functions. However, more comprehensive support is justified since the 
Government has decided that local agencies will have the key responsibility for addressing both 
environmental and natural resource problems, and for providing services to mitigate such 
problems. In the current fiscal environment, establishing of such services will require that local 
agencies find financing mechanisms that minimize direct Government financial cost. A range of 
financing  options  needs  to  be  assessed,  including  alternative  cost  recovery  mechanisms, 
collection of resource rents, and public-private provision. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The Project Preparatory Technical Assistance (TA) will prepare a sector investment 
project that will address priority natural resource and environmental problems in key subsectors. 
The ensuing project will assist the Government to (i) establish a comprehensive, integrated 
NREM framework; (ii) implement priority investments; and (iii) develop efficient systems for 
effectively managing natural resources and the environment. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will involve a number of interdependent stages, which will form the basis for a 
sector investment project. They are (i) identification of priority natural resource and environment 
problems at the subsector level; (ii) pilot case studies in 2–3 priority subsectors to determine the 
requirements for developing efficient NREM systems (policy, legislative, institutional), and for 
providing services that will be required to manage and mitigate specific problems and impacts; 
(iii) preparation of an NREM framework; and (iv) integration of the outcomes in stages (i)–(iii) of 
the TA into a sector investment project. 
 
13.  The TA will help the Government develop selection criteria to rank and prioritize natural 
resource and  environmental problems at the subsector level. Case studies in 2–3 priority 
subsectors and representative pilot sites will identify the requirements for effective and efficient 
NREM, and for providing of services to manage and mitigate specific problems. At these pilot 
sites, the focus will be to develop management systems that detail institutional responsibility, 
management needs, and supporting investment requirements. Where the site-specific problems 
require  the  provision  of  services  to  mitigate  or  manage  adverse  impacts,  such  as  water 
pollution, solid waste management, and degradation of community-based natural resources, 
protected areas, and ecologically significant sites, options for sustainable financing of such 
services will be assessed. These case studies will be important in giving practical feedback from

4 
the field for the policy, legal, regulatory, and institutional requirements that will be used in 
preparing the NREM framework. Further, the case studies will identify the investment and 
implementation  requirements  for  indicative  activities  in  those  subsectors,  a  key  input  in 
preparing the sector investment project. 
 
14.  Preparing an NREM framework will involve helping the Government review and assess 
the  existing  management  systems;  the  policy,  legal,  and  institutional  structures;  and  the 
associated social aspects. It will be particularly important to include all regions of the country. 
From this analysis, recommendations and an implementation manual will be prepared for 
Government endorsement to improve the management systems. In the subsectors where the 
problems  and  impacts  will  require  provision  of  services,  the  options  for  financially  viable 
provision of services will be assessed–public-private provision, alternative approaches to cost 
recovery, and requirements for effective public management and supervision of such services. 
An operational manual will be prepared to help local government agencies select appropriate 
financing options and establish effective performance monitoring systems. The TA will support 
the Government in preparing a draft natural resources policy, and the required supporting 
policy, legal, and institutional reform agendas, including detailed time-bound action plans. The 
reform agendas will be implemented in the sector investment project.   
 
15.  The sector investment project will be based on the outcomes of the TA activities, in 
particular, (i) the identified requirements to implement an NREM framework, with the associated 
policy, legal, and institutional reforms; (ii) the technical and operational capacity building needs; 
and (iii) the selection criteria for prioritizing subsectors that the project will support and the 
investment subprojects that will address priority natural resource and environment problems. 
The pilot case studies and the feasibility studies will indicate the types of investment required. 
The sector investment project will be prepared in standard ADB format, and the terms of 
reference in Appendix 2 detail these requirements.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,040,000 equivalent with a foreign exchange 
cost of $642,000 and a local currency cost of $398,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $800,000, comprising the entire foreign exchange cost and local 
currency cost of $158,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the Japan 
Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will provide the balance of 
the  local  currency  costs,  equivalent  to  $240,000,  by  financing  $104,0005  to  pay  for  TA 
workshops, vehicle hire, and 18 person-months of domestic consultant input (sociologist and 
social survey team), and in-kind contributions through provision of office facilities, staff, and 
services. The ADB financing will cover all 22 person-months of international consultant and 40 
of the 58 person-months of domestic consultant costs, international and local travel, reports and 
communications,  contract  administration  services,  office  equipment,  furniture,  and  office 
supplies. Detailed cost estimates for the TA  are in Appendix 3. The Government has been 
advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
                                                 
5  MENR will finance $104,000 directly, utilizing loan funds from the World Bank Environmental Action 1 Program. 
The External Resources Department, Ministry of Policy Implementation, and the World Bank have been consulted 
and have concurred.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be MENR. The active participation of a number of 
stakeholders will be required, as the TA will address issues that are linked with activities of other 
ministries in the sector. To guide the TA, the Government will form an interministerial natural 
resource and environment advisory committee under the leadership of the secretary of MENR. 
The committee will include representatives from all relevant stakeholders, including but not 
limited  to  the  following:    the  Ministry  of  Lands,  regional  ministries,  Central  Environmental 
Authority, Ministry of Home Affairs, provincial councils and local governments, Ministry of 
Irrigation and Water Resources, Ministry of Tourism, academia, nongovernment organizations, 
and the private sector. The committee will review and endorse recommendations on behalf of 
the Government. 
 
18.  MENR and the relevant ministries will identify and ensure adequate participation of 
counterpart staff to work directly with the consultants. Working groups will be established to 
support specific TA activities, such as the pilot case studies. These groups will be established 
on a needs basis, and will be operational and technically focused. They will include relevant 
stakeholders and will be led by the key agency responsible for that activity.   
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over a 12-month period, starting in mid-February 2003 and 
ending in January 2004.  The consultant team will prepare an inception report within 3 weeks of 
the start of the TA, an interim report at the end of month 6; a midterm report at month 9; and a 
draft final report that will include a detailed feasibility report 11 months after the start.  The 
inception, midterm, and draft final reports will be subject to tripartite reviews, which will involve 
ADB, the Government, and the consulting firm.   
 
20.  The  ADB-financed  consulting  services  will  be  provided  through  a  consulting  firm 
recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants using the quality and 
cost-based  selection  method,  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging 
domestic consultants. ADB’s simplified technical proposal procedures will be applied. The 
Government will be responsible for recruiting the Government-financed consulting services, in 
accordance  with  ADB's  guidelines  or  other  procedures  acceptable  to  ADB  for  recruiting 
domestic  consultants.  The  TA  budget  provides  for  the  purchase  of  office  equipment  and 
computers. The consultants will procure those items in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for 
Procurement. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Sri Lanka for the purpose of preparing the Delivering Natural Resource and 
Environmental Management Services Sector Project, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka: 
Sri Lanka considers 27% of the population in 1995 to be in poverty, with a larger group of the population considered 
vulnerable as they fall slightly above current poverty thresholds.  Studies reveal that the levels of consumption poverty are 
significantly higher than those of human poverty, indicating that poverty is linked more to income levels than to access to 
basic social services.  
 
In effect, the poor have less assets–human, physical, and natural–and those assets they do have attract lower returns 
when they interact with market and social opportunities to generate income. In Sri Lanka over 90% of the poor live in rural 
areas. Further, 42% of the poor are farmers with small plots of land of less than 0.4 hectare (ha), and the land is generally 
classified as having low productive capacity.  With rising population, the current land per capita ratio will continue to fall 
from around 0.35 ha to 0.25 ha by 2030. Pressure will increase on households in terms of livelihoods, vulnerably, and 
poverty. One outcome is likely to be an increase in population living in urban environments.  
 
The country poverty strategy identifies the causes of poverty as  (i) lack of assets, especially land; (ii) imperfect property 
rights and miniature sizes of holdings; (iii) shortfalls in access to water;  (iv) weak institutional arrangements and practices; 
(v) noncompetitive product markets for farm produce; (vi) limited technology adoption and use in rural industries; (vii) poor 
production standards and low product quality in rural industries; (viii) high capital costs; (ix) raw material and resource 
bottlenecks; (x) limited access to production and marketing information; (xi) shortfalls in physical infrastructure, such as 
inadequate power, energy, and communications; and (xii) the absence of high mobility roads and a transport network 
linking villages, towns, and cities. 
 
Access to natural resources currently underpins the ability of many poor to escape from poverty.  Current forecasts of 
demographic and economic growth suggest that the overall demand for natural resources within the Sri Lankan economy 
will increase by approximately 50% above the existing level of resource demand within 20 years. Given the high level of 
consumption poverty and the large group assessed as vulnerable, Sri Lanka faces a growing poverty risk if effective 
resource and environmental management systems are not established.   Without effective management, the outlook is one 
of declining natural resource productivity and environmental conditions, with an associated increase in vulnerability and 
poverty. 
 
The Government's proposed poverty reduction strategy identifies seven priority areas: (i) achieving peace; (ii) maintaining a 
stable macroeconomic environment; (iii) improving market access by linking poor regions to dynamic markets; (iv) fostering 
productivity improvement and broader market access for small- and medium-scale enterprises; (v) creating opportunities for 
the poor to benefit from structural change by fostering broad-based rural development, competitive industrialization, service 
sector development, and sound urban settlement; (vi) improving access to quality education and health care; and (vii) 
environmental management to enhance the sustainability of the poverty reduction process. 
 
The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  the  Government  program  to  address  poverty  by 
strengthening natural resource and environmental management (NREM) systems, and developing effective delivery 
systems for providing of these services. Support will involve institutional strengthening and developing appropriate 
governance systems. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Classification: Poverty intervention 
The poverty analysis will include (i) a desk study of secondary data sources; (ii) a structured survey as an input for the 
initial social analysis and the TA delivery process; (iii) follow-on, issue-based focus groups; (iv) a consultation process at 
pilot sites with social impact evaluations to review the potential contribution to both poverty reduction and social well-
being; and (v) an institutional assessment of community and nongovernment organization capacity.  
 
The desk study will review the existing data sets and reports on the social and poverty status of Sri Lanka and the effects 
(predicted and actual) of NREM systems.  The secondary data will be used to develop a regional and district- 
disaggregated database that will be used for selecting pilot sites and for designing the social survey.  The social survey 
will be undertaken at the household level and will use a stratified sample across the five regional administrations.  The 
sample will be stratified by district and local authority, poverty and social status.  Data will be collected to have 
disaggregated data for gender, poverty (both consumption and human poverty), social status, and resource access 
parameters.  The potential for using the survey as an input to the next State of the Environment Report will be explored.

It is recommended that the survey, which will involve face-to-face interviews, be undertaken by experienced enumerators.  
Issues identified during the analysis of survey data will be presented to the TA team, working groups, and advisory 
committees to develop an issue-based agenda for focus groups.  Focus groups will be implemented mostly in association 
with the pilot sites, except for topics that require a wider stakeholder input, for example, community-based approaches 
and legal issues. The purpose of the focus group is to explore in greater depth stakeholder perceptions, preferences, and 
attitudes, and to integrate them into the implementation of pilot site programs and the definition of NREM systems and 
supporting policy, legal, and institutional reforms.   
 
The social analysis will also review and assess the local nongovernment institutions in terms of their need for capacity 
development, the options for networking the agencies and the proposed programs, and the relationship of these groups 
with local stakeholders, the natural resource and environmental planning process, and policy development. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder identification and involvement are critical components of the TA implementation strategy.  Stakeholders will 
include government agencies at the national, regional, and local levels, as well as nongovernment organizations, 
community-based organizations, community members, and representatives of the private sector.  The TA will use a 
steering committee, advisory committee, and working groups to build stakeholder involvement and ownership in decision 
making.  Further consultation will be essential, and a social communication program is included in the design to ensure 
outreach and awareness. Wide consultation programs are planned and will be followed up within the proposed loan 
program to achieve consensus on policy, legal, and institutional reforms and procedures.  The focus of the TA and 
subsequent loan on natural resource and environment delivery systems will provide opportunities for involvement in 
planning and decision making, as well as implementation–where pro-poor strategies are to be developed.  
 
Participation strategy required:  The consultants will develop a participation strategy for both the TA and the follow-on 
loan.  The TA plan will be integrated with the social communication and pilot delivery site activities.

8  Appendix 2 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will help the Government prepare a 
sector investment project that will address priority natural resource and environmental problems 
in key subsectors. To achieve that objective, the TA will support the Government in preparing a 
comprehensive    integrated  natural  resource  and  environmental  management  (NREM) 
framework,  in  developing  efficient  systems,  and  in  defining  the  requirements  in  providing 
services to effectively manage natural resources and the environment.  Selection criteria will be 
established to prioritize subsectors, and natural resource and environmental problems.  
 
A.  Natural Resource and Environmental Management Case Studies 
2.  The TA will prepare case studies based on the identified priorities in 2–3 subsectors. 
Representative pilot sites will be selected, and used to identify and assess the requirements for 
effective and efficient NREM. At the pilot sites, the focus  will be to develop management 
systems  that  detail  institutional  responsibility,  management  needs,  and  the  supporting 
investment requirements. Where the problem will require the provision of services to mitigate or 
manage adverse impacts, options for financing such services through cost recovery, resource 
rents, and public-private provision will be assessed. The case studies will be important in 
providing practical feedback on the policy, legal, regulatory, and institutional requirements that 
will be used in preparing the NREM framework. Further, the case studies will identify the 
investment and implementation requirements for indicative activities in those subsectors, and 
the information will be a key input in preparing the sector investment project. The consultant will 
complete the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Identify priority natural resource and environment problems and opportunities 
through desk studies, consultations, and a series of workshops at the regional 
and local authority levels, focusing on strategic problems and opportunities. 
(ii)  In consultation with the Government, agree on the selection criteria and priorities 
for pilot case studies, and the site locations. 
(iii)  Establish working groups under the leadership of the responsible agency, to 
guide the pilot case studies. 
(iv)  Obtain consensus on a process for defining the roles, responsibilities, and rights 
that will underpin the identification of management options and the development 
of implementation strategies. 
(v)  Undertake a participatory process for identifying of management strategies and 
associated implementation plans. 
(vi)  Assess appropriate service delivery financing options and develop the required 
documentation for attracting finance. 
(vii)  Prepare a performance monitoring system that will allow assessment of the 
management and system performance. 
(viii)  Prepare a brief summary of lessons learned in the case studies in terms of 
policy, legal, and institutional requirements of implementation. 
 
B.  Natural Resource and Environmental Management Framework 
3.  The TA will help the Government review and assess existing management systems; 
environmental  and  physical  planning  processes;  policy,  legal,  and  institutional  structures; 
provision of services; and associated social aspects. This assessment will cover all regions of 
the  country.  From  this  analysis,  the  TA  will  prepare  recommendations–for  government

Appendix 2  9 
endorsement–for developing a comprehensive NREM framework, and a draft natural resource 
policy that gives in detail the required reform agendas and the requirements in providing 
services to mitigate and manage priority problems. 
 
1.  Management Systems 
4.  The  consultant  will  support  the  Government  in  assessing  existing  NREM  systems, 
including planning processes and provision of services, and to develop improved planning and 
management systems. The consultant will complete the following tasks: 
 
a.  Planning  
(i)  Review existing Government national, regional, and local authority NREM 
and  planning  procedures,  including  lessons  learned  from  externally 
assisted projects and international experience in NREM. 
(ii)  Assess the needs for NREM based on consultation at regional, provincial, 
district, and local levels. 
(iii)  Complete  a  management  information  systems  review,  and  identify 
requirements for inclusion in the recommended management framework. 
(iv)  Prepare recommendations on management systems, and submit a draft 
paper detailing the recommended options to the natural resource and 
environment advisory committee for review and endorsement. 
(v)  Prepare  an  implementation  manual  that  outlines  the  operational 
requirements to establish the NREM framework. 
 
b.  Provision of Services 
 
(i)  For the subsectors where the problems and impacts will require provision 
of services, assess the options available for financially viable and feasible 
provision  of  such  services.  The  options  encompass  public–private 
provision, cost recovery, and systems for resource rent collections. 
(ii)  Identify institutional capacity and management systems requirements for 
government  agencies  to  provide  effective  supervision  and  public 
management of such services. 
(iii)  Prepare a working paper outlining the feasible and viable interventions, 
and submit it to the natural resource and environment advisory committee 
for review and endorsement. 
(iv)  Develop effective performance monitoring systems for managing these 
services. 
(v)  Prepare a manual to assist government agencies in selecting appropriate 
financing options for providing such services. 
 
2.  Policy, Legal, and Institutional Reform   
5.  The consultant will support the Government in preparing a draft natural resource policy, 
and supporting policy, legal/regulatory, and institutional reform agendas including time-bound 
action plans. The consultant will complete the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review  and  assess  the  existing  NREM  framework,  including  policy,  legal, 
institutional, and social aspects:

(a)  Identify  current  Government  approaches  to  natural  resource  and 
environment  policy  and  management,  and  community-based 
management approaches. 
(b)  Assess and analyze existing compliance and enforcement mechanisms. 
(c)  Identify constraints and inconsistencies within the NREM framework, and 
linkages  to  other  government  policies  and  programs,  including  land 
resource and resettlement policies. 
(d)  Review the status of existing information systems, identify constraints, 
and prepare recommendations to address shortfalls. 
 
(ii)  Prepare an issues paper on natural resource policy that integrates the findings of 
the policy, legal/regulatory, and institutional assessments, and includes relevant 
findings and data from the social analysis. Submit this paper to the natural 
resource and environment advisory committee for review and endorsement. 
(iii)  Help the Government prepare a draft natural resource policy, and submit this 
draft to an expert panel for technical review. Following revisions, submit the draft 
policy  to  the  natural  resource  and  environment  advisory  committee  for 
endorsement. Include in the draft a work plan for implementing a comprehensive 
consultation program. 
(iv)  Prepare policy, legal, and institutional reform agendas with time-bound action 
plans for inclusion in the policy and institutional strengthening activities in the 
sector project. 
 
C.  Social Needs and Participation 
6.  The consultant will prepare a social and poverty analysis for both the TA and the 
investment study, and will complete the following tasks: 
 
(i)  With the team leader, prepare a TA stakeholder consultation plan for inclusion in 
the inception report. 
(ii)  Develop poverty profiles for each of the five regions, using secondary data 
validated through the household survey. 
(iii)  Undertake a stratified household survey in identified priority areas to assess the 
role and importance of natural resource and land resources, and to determine the 
association between natural  resources and poverty status. Assess the relative 
importance of natural resources in household livelihoods. Disaggregate the data 
by income quintile and gender. 
(iv)  Complete in-depth interviews, and form issue-based focus groups to assess 
stakeholder  perceptions  of  critical  issues  that  are  identified  during  both  the 
household survey and the policy and planning development process. 
(v)  Assess the existing and potential role of the nongovernment sector in policy and 
planning processes, under the TA and in the proposed follow-on loan. 
(vi)  Prepare recommendations and guidelines on stakeholder participation in the 
planning process, and identify necessary capacity-building requirements. 
(vii)  Facilitate  policy  development  and  planning  process  workshops  for  TA 
implementation. 
(viii)  Develop socially based criteria to be included among the selection criteria for 
identifying  priority  subsectors  and  sites  for  intervention,  and  indicative 
subprojects that would require investment under the proposed loan. 
(ix)  Assess stakeholder capacity and the requirements to strengthen and improve the 
effectiveness of civil society participation in natural resource and environmental

management  and  planning.  Prepare  recommendations  on  implementing 
proposed changes. 
 
D.  Sector Investment Project   
7.  With the support of the Government, the consultant will prepare a sector investment 
project. The sector project is likely to include policy, legal, and institutional reform, and capacity 
building to establish an NREM framework, and to develop efficient systems and provision of 
services to effectively manage and mitigate the adverse impacts on natural resources and the 
environment in identified priority subsectors. The consultant will complete the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Undertake regular consultations with all stakeholders to develop consensus on 
the rationale and scope for the proposed loan. 
(ii)  Prepare a problem analysis and a project logical framework. 
(iii)  Define selection criteria for prioritizing the subsectors and proposed subsector 
investment projects. Apply the criteria in all regions of the country. Include natural 
resource, environmental, ecological, social, institutional, and financial aspects. 
(iv)  Formulate project components, ensuring consultation and coordination among 
stakeholders including nongovernment organizations, local authorities, district 
secretary, regional and national agencies. 
(v)  Review alternative implementation systems, and prepare recommendations for 
implementing regional natural resource and environment investment subprojects, 
and arrangements for coordinating and monitoring these subprojects. 
(vi)  Based on (i)–(v), finalize the overall project design, including implementation and 
procurement arrangements, and final costing, and coordinate the preparation of a 
draft and final report suitable for appraisal by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). 
(vii)  Prepare a feasibility study for the proposed investment program and assess the 
financial and economic feasibility of the investment program by completing these 
tasks: 
 
(a)  Assess  the  economic  implications  of  the  recommended  policy  and 
institutional issues identified during the policy and planning phase, giving 
particular attention to compliance costs. 
(b)  Assess  the  potential  revenue  mobilization  needs  and  options  for  the 
regional and local administration. 
(c)  Prepare detailed costings on each component and the overall project 
cost, using COSTAB software. Costs will include foreign exchange (direct 
and  indirect  costs),  local  cost  components,  and  physical  and  price 
contingencies.  Prepare  a  financing  plan  with  contributions  from  the 
Government, ADB, the private sector, and beneficiaries. 
(d)  Assess the economic and financial benefits for each project component. 
(e)  Undertake economic and financial analyses of indicative investments to 
be financed by the project, and assess recurrent costs and implications 
for  participating  entities  and  beneficiaries,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. 
(f)  Prepare an overall justification for the project proposal.  
 
(viii)  Complete a TA fact-finding stage social assessment of the proposed project.  In 
the  assessment,  identify  the  expected  beneficiaries  and  communities  to  be 
affected and follow ADB’s  Handbook  on  Poverty  and  Social  Analysis.  Give

minorities  on  social  assessment.  Should  resettlement  be  identified,  include

(ix)  Undertake an initial environmental examination (IEE) of the proposed investment

(x)  Prepare a project performance monitoring system that will allow effective project

E.  Consulting Services   
8.  The tasks described in the terms of reference will require consultants (person-months 
are in parenthesis) with the following expertise. International consultants will include a natural 
resource/environmental  management  and  planning  specialist/team  leader  (10),  institutional 
specialist (3), information systems/database specialist (2), natural resource economist and 
financial analyst (3), management specialist in public utilities (2), and a sociologist (2). The 
domestic  consultants  will  include  a  natural  resource/environmental  specialist  policy  and 
planning  specialist  (10),  senior  lawyer  (6),  specialist  lawyer  for  specific  legal  issues  (2), 
institutional specialist (6), information systems and database specialist (4), awareness, media 
and  communications  specialist  (3),  natural  resource  economist  and  financial  analyst  (3), 
environmentalist (2), natural resource and environmental engineer (4), sociologist (8), and the 
social survey team (10). 
 
F.  Reports 
 
9.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months, starting in mid-February 2003 and ending 
January 2004.  The consultant team will prepare an inception report within 3 weeks of start; an 
interim report at the end of month 6; a midterm report at month 9; and a draft final report, which 
will include a detailed feasibility report, 11 months after the TA starts. The inception, midterm, 
and  draft  final  reports  will  be  subject  to  tripartite  reviews,  which  will  involve  ADB,  the 
Government, and the consulting firm.
